line_1: Pereene, the pride of Indian dames,
There's none can number all those vertuous Dames
line_2: Which chose cold death before their lovers flames.

line_1: Or as, again, your Courtly Dames,
YE gentle nymphs and generous dames
line_2: Be sure ye soothe their amorous flames,

line_1: These scenes, of old how fam'd for beauteous dames!
line_2: And Blenheim now the palm of beauty claims.
As for them, I applaud their high aims;

line_1: Where an order I hear is created for Dames
line_2: of high Beauty and wit and Poetical Fames

line_1: And sure of all mankind the Squire of Dames
line_2: Who aye, untouch'd by any foreign flames,

line_1: As e'er inspir'd the antient Grecian Dames:
line_2: Our Souls would kindle with as gen'rous Flames,

line_1: No frantic shouts of Thracian dames,
line_2: No Satyrs fierce with savage flames

line_1: Though, like the royal German dames,
line_2: It bears an hundred Christian names;

line_1: Scarce known to the fastidious dames,
line_2: Nor skill'd to call them by their names.

line_1: Full of the majesty of city dames,
line_2: Raise strange emotions and invidious flames.

line_1: Sure Troy, so hateful to the Grecian Dames,
line_2: Is ruin'd now, with dire, consuming Flames;
Then gather round the mounting Flames,
What, tho' far from silver Thames,
